text:
What does a function like this do:
`(f::FastDense)(x,p) = f.σ.(reshape(p[1:(f.out*<http://f.in|f.in>)],f.out,<http://f.in|f.in>)*x .+  p[(f.out*<http://f.in|f.in>+1):end] )`
for a struct like this:
`struct FastDense{F,F2} <: FastLayer`
  `out::Int`
  `in::Int`
  `σ::F`
  `initial_params::F2`
  `function FastDense(in::Integer, out::Integer,σ = identity, initW = Flux.glorot_uniform, initb = Flux.zeros)`

elements.text: What does a function like this do:
function FastDense(in::Integer, out::Integer,σ = identity, initW = Flux.glorot_uniform, initb = Flux.zeros)

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
it defines how `FastDense` objects can act like functions themselves

elements.text: objects can act like functions themselves

text: maybe you can say which particular parts of the syntax you don't understand

text: E.g., given `layer = FastDense(20, 2, …)`, it defines what happens when you do `layer(x, p)`

text: <@UH8A351DJ> I am confused that by calling (f::FastDense)(x,p) are we making an object by running the function Fastdense with the x and p putting values in σ and initial_params or in `in` and `out`(like normal function would behave)

elements.text: I am confused that by calling (f::FastDense)(x,p) are we making an object by running the function Fastdense with the x and p putting values in σ and initial_params or in

text: `f` is an instance of `FastDense`, this function is defining what happens when you call a instance of FastDence
